title: At what stage of your manuscript do you share it with people? Do you wait until it's been edited or do you share early drafts? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thanks for the A2A. At what stage of your manuscript do you share it with people? Do you wait until it's been edited or do you share early drafts? I will share works in progress (WIP) with a select few trusted fellow authors I exchange things with, but I usually only do this when I am looking for advice or affirmation that I pulled something off I was trying to do. I learned a long time ago to not trust people with a partially edited draft. If you are just asking an opinion, they’ll probably try to edit all the mistakes for you. If you are asking a small publisher who is over zealous, you may find it published before you were ready. If you show a partial draft to someone who is really excited about the idea, they may never stop bugging you about when it will be done. (Not good for someone like me who likes to juggle a lot of projects and back-burner some for months at at time.) OR…what if I decide not to finish it at all? I don’t even like to share my ideas for future ones with my wife anymore. “Whatever happened to that one you were going to write that was bigger than Game of Thrones but set in space?” Yeah. Not writing that one. Bad idea to start with. (That wasn’t the actual idea, btw.) There are a couple that she just won’t let go. Not going to write them, Dear! I generally don’t like to share anything, even if I am co-writing and exchanging chapters of a WIP with another author, until I am satisfied that it is “good enough” if it got “leaked to the public”. Not that that would ever happen. I’m not that famous and I trust the people I work with anyways, but it’s kind of an “always put your best foot forward” thing. I did have something published I wasn’t ready to let go of (more than once actually) and I just don’t go there anymore.
response.upvotes: View 2 Upvoters

response.answer_text: I don’t. I may pass it on to a beta reader once the final product has been edited for the umpteenth time, but no one sees or touches it until then. Most often, my agent is the first person to read it. When you over-saturate people with whatever you’re writing, they will get bored of it. The story isn’t theirs, so reading it so many times over is just going to kill it for them. Another reason I don’t is because people like to think they are editors. Most are definitely not. When I was in school I let a few of my friends and teachers read my very first manuscript, and got back so much feedback it was impossible to sort through it all, and a good majority of it was useless. You should add dragons! I don’t understand this word. Can you put me in the story? Where’s my character? I don’t like omniscient point-of-view. I think you should rewrite this whole section to include fairies. And then there are the people who get immediately obsessed. They will harass you, hound you, beg you for more pages. They want inside information now! They want to be included in the story. They want a dedication. They want to know everything about everything to do with the story, regardless of whether you want to reveal it or even have it planned out. They will get upset when you tell them no. They will get pissy when you don’t write full chapters in a day. For me, it’s just not worth the trouble. It’s your work; allowing other people into it often invites unneeded criticisms and involvement. That’s why, while I may talk about it to my husband or my trusty old friend, no one reads it until it’s published, outside of my professional team.
response.upvotes: View 3 Upvoters

response.answer_text: For me, I’ve found sharing my manuscripts with others before they are completed is a death sentence for the piece, so I seldom even talk about it to others. Any type of sharing messes it up. Strangely, I find the same thing in my personal life. If I tell someone about a relationship that has just started, it seems to jinx the affair! Once a manuscript is finished: shaped, corrected, ending, beginning, all loose ends tied together, I’ll share the manuscript with a trusted friend or peer and always get an input I didn’t expect and can often incorporate. I have conducted writers workshops for many years and I have been a member of many many. In a workshop you read perhap 5 pages of a manuscript, then everyone discusses it aloud. If you don’t have thick skin, you hate this. People also write on the manuscript you read from and a passed-out. I’ve kept every manuscript I ever read in a workshop because the comments occasionally are invaluable. You don’t understand what people are saying when you start. You don’t exactly understand what: “Turn up the heat in the kitchen means.” Sometimes, you are so embarrassed, you can’t even hear! What writers are like bread, they are only dough until they get heat in a workshop, then they thrive.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Sharing your work with “people” is not productive, in my view. Let me ask you this…if you were a painter of landscapes, when you just had the underlying colors on the canvas, would you call “people” in to take a look? If you were a carpenter or a cobbler, and your work was just half finished, would you have “people” drop by to give an opinion? You are engaged in “creative writing.” If you are constantly having someone else give you their thoughts on creative qualities, how is that your creation? I admit that I have let my children read some of my stories and I have let my girlfriend read one or two, and of course, guess what happened? I received glowing reports of my brilliance. Bullshit! I wax a bit like Hemmingway here, but bullshit. Really! No one is brilliant right out of the box. A publisher will usually tell you the truth about your writing and best listen to it but even then, they have an agenda. To sell what they publish, but they also know what will sell. Selling is not always in line with creative thought. So, if I were you, I would have a pristine, edited, grammatically correct manuscript and then let the world have at it. It better be good, because the public is mean-spirited. Christopher Hitchens once said, “Everybody does have a book in them, but in most cases, that's where it should stay.” Be a skeptic. Question everything in your life and what you think you know. Use the bywords of Honor, Truth, Reason, and Logic in your life and you will be much happier and more fulfilled for doing so.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: I wait a bit until I’m well into a first draft before sharing. And at that stage I only share with fellow writers in a small writers’ group . Like many other writers I find early comments distracting. I take to heart Coleridge’s experience with his poem Kubla Kahn. A friend visited him while he was writing and he lost the vision that had stimulated the work. Agonizing later, he wrote: “Could I revive within me Her symphony and song, To such a deep delight ’twould win me, That with music loud and long, I would build that dome in air, That sunny dome! those caves of ice!” But he lost that thread and we’ll never know what the poem may have been like. Such is why I write as I do, a pantser who writes by the seat of my pants. I can go back and gussy up what I have written but never accurately recall what I didn’t write down. I do trust the perspicacious writers I know who can comment effectively after the fact. One friend, a retired screen writer, rescued me from some too-florid prose in my recent Vietnam War novel, A Shepherd to Fools. His view was invaluable, coming early but not intrusively. So my advice in a nutshell, share only when you are ready and when your idea is already well begun.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: I will answer for manuscripts of academic articles. I share it with different people at different stages. First key ideas and contributions (when I know I have enough contributions to build a paper)Who: At this point I share it with the co-authors. Generally in my case my thesis supervisors, and/or someone else. Why: early feedback on the central ideas (how relevant, interesting is it), on the method etc. The layout is still messy, the structure is not there. 2. Working draft (things are being added, the key contributions are there but it’s working the form, building a structure) Who: several rounds with the co-authors. When I have something I consider decent, I may also send it to close friends that are in the domain. Why: During this process, I try to highlight what has to be read, the key changes in the new version (it does not always work, co-authors never read or react to the part you expect them to). Sending it to close friends is for external feedback and because I value their opinion. Also, the work may be of interest for them. 3. Submitted manuscript Who: finally submitted phew! I feel ok sending it to people requesting it and it’s generally on a preprint server such as arXiv. Why: sure, it has not been reviewed and edited so it’s not perfect, but I value science in the open and transparency, showing the work done has some value to others, signals the topics I am working on and I am ready to accept small typos for this.

In my field of scientific writing in mathematics I proceed in the following way: I typically do not speak about the kind of work I am doing. If you speak about early draft or unfinished stuff you risk embarrassment if it does not turn out to work. Better the total comfort of total secrecy.If I am sure that it will turn out successful, then I start to announce the result to colleagues that I know and trust. Maybe something will come out of this like advice, examples to consider, possible extensions, etc.When the writing is done I put on arXiv.org e-Print archive for people to see. Arxiv provides by itself a proof of authorship. I wait typically 10 days after this preprint submission before submitting to a formal journal. In that period, I may receive useful comments and invitations to submit.Therefore, the strategy is when doing sharing not to expose oneself to potential trouble and be cornered into impossible situation.
response.upvotes: View 2 Upvoters

response.answer_text: Whatever I’m writing, I share it with my writing group to get feedback. I share stuff with my wife because she helps me edit There is a rule that says write your first draft through to the end without editing or you will never get it done. I break this rule with my writing group because I can’t bring them a competed novel first draft and expect them to read it in the limited time we have at our weekly meetings, while at the same time I don’t want to bring in a raw first draft. They get to look at a first and a half or second draft, slightly edited to make it tolerable. My wife usually gets an almost read draft just before submission so she can do her editing magic without wasting her time. No one else gets to read my stuff until it’s ready.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Hello, Dane. My preference is to wait until I have a substantial chunk of material for which I want critical reader feedback — perhaps 100 pages or more, though it depends on the nature of the work. It’s got to be enough to let readers know the premise of the work and the way I’m handling it in terms of language, structure, intent and development. I share the material with close connections I consider beta readers. These are thoughtful people. They’re competent readers who will challenge the work when necessary, regardless of the nature of their connections with me. In other words, I can trust them to give me meaningful feedback before I get so deeply into the work that major changes would be problematic. I’ll take their comments and criticisms into account in revising what I’ve done, and I’ll then come back to them down the road when I have more (and more developed) material for them to look at. Ultimately, you’ll have to handle the business of “early readers” in a way and at a time that makes you comfortable and provides you with the sort of feedback you need. As always, your mileage may vary.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: It depends. Usually I have at least worked the drafts, edited at the minimum with Grammerly, then it goes to my first readers. I might discuss plots early on with a small group who live in my stories! That’s kind of fun. They will often take a part of my Code Raven Series and tell me what they’d love to see. It’s great to share but not when your MS is a mess. It’s a waste of very valuable time from those who lend a hand for basically the thrill of it. Now if you are using content editors that might change things. Or I have one book critic who has become a close friend. I can ask him for suggestions, ideas, or early reads of a chapter. But I have to be prepared for major criticism if I’m showing unpolished work.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Thanks for your request Dane. I’m a book editor rather than a writer, but I can tell you what I’ve noticed when working with clients. Most of the nonfiction authors I work with tend to share their work when it’s fully written. Sometimes, they’ve asked friends or family for opinions or shared the book with beta readers to get feedback, but often I’m the first person to read the book. After our first collaboration, some authors prefer to share their second books part-way through writing to get feedback sooner. I might be biased saying this as an editor, but seeking an objective editorial assessment from an experienced, knowledgeable editor who understands the market and the target audience is likely to add more value than asking friends or family.
response.upvotes: View 1 Upvoter

response.answer_text: My own policy is not to show the manuscript to anyone until the manuscript has been written and edited several times. After that, I MAY show it to one person just to get a trusted read but you have to be careful with that because that person is entitled to their opinion and will give you their opinion because you have asked them to do so. That may change the way you edit the final copy and you have to balance that possibility against the possible improvement to the manuscript. In general, unless you have someone whose opinion you really trust and who knows you well enough to understand how you work and what you want to accomplish, I would not show it to anyone before it is published.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Question: At what stage of your manuscript do you share it with people? Do you wait until it’s been edited or do you share early drafts? Answer: I complete Version 1. That’s a full complete draft, complete iwth indexes, appendices, and anything else that should be included. Then I put it out to my beta readers, and leave it to ferment for a while. I need to do that so that I can come back to it with some objectivity myself. When I think I have enough distance, then I return to it armed with the responses of the beta readers, and see what’s to be done with it. Once I think I know what’s to be done, I either get on with doing it, or at that point I may involve an editor. This is a slow way, in terms of elapsed time, to produce a book, but it work for me. Hope this helps.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Unless I am sharing with a trusted workshop group and looking for help to brainstorm something, I try to revise before I share. I have been in situations where I met weekly with a group, and in order to have something to share, I brought something that wasn’t heavily edited. To be honest, though, I don’t get much out of sharing things before they’re finished. A good workshop group, however, can be a great help when it comes to finding plot holes. They often ask questions that help me to develop my characters, so manuscripts are also not “finished” yet either.

I don't share early drafts, because I tend to go back and revise in light of later developments, so the early drafts do not represent the finished product. I took a class from James Patterson, and he recommended having one or two people read each chapter as you go along and give you feedback on pace, characters and dialogue. I tried it, but it wasn't helpful due to my process of editing and revision. Patterson must create finished product chapter by chapter. I don't.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Personally, I would never share an early draft. That's like taking the cake out of the oven too soon. It's your vision, and it shouldn't be exposed to comment until you have done the very best you can with it. Sure, you might have to make changes later, but my advice, the advice I always gave when I taught at Byron Community College was to protect your novel from everyone while it's still in process. Thanks for the A2A, Dane, and best wishes for the new year, Dani.
response.upvotes: View 1 Upvoter

response.answer_text: I wait until I think it’s done. I’m generally wrong, but that’s the time when I have the most questions and need the most feedback. Have I done it? Or is the difficulty I see a reality? Is there something I’ve missed? Where are the holes? This is when I need the most help both with what I think might be a problem and the problems I don’t see at all. It goes out for first reads. After that feedback, it goes to its editor.
response.upvotes: View 1 Upvoter

response.answer_text: I have a critique group that meets twice a month and we'll read short pieces to each other to get some feedback. But beyond that, I don't share my manuscript with beta readers until it's done and I've gone through it a couple of times making my own revisions. Until then it's just too poorly written to share and it embarrasses me to know that people read my poorly written sentences.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: Erm, depends what you mean by “share”. Nothing goes to my publisher/editor until it’s been through at least 3 edits by me, and I’m reasonably satisfied with it. Other than that, nobody gets to see a single word until it’s published, and even then I have to tell you that neither friends or family know I write, or are aware of my nom de plume. It’s too personal - I would shrivel if a friend read some of my stuff and hated it!
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Dane John Cobain

response.answer_text: As the publishing & media in the UK is very much a closed shop for wealthy, connected , predominantly white midde-class people & their cronies, I sometimes put samples of my work out unfinished to attract potential financiers, producers and collaborators. When I have submitted highly original & near complete sci fi ideas / manuscripts to standard media places, I found they stole my idea and rejected my work, to profit from it. Hope this helps.

response.answer_text: You can share it with a Beta reader who might read it for content AND any editing problems. Whether it is edited or not, wait until you finish the book to get an overall opinion on what you have done. You might let a reader sample a partial of what you’ve started just to see if you have enough “snap” in the first part of the book to draw a reader in—a good Hook.

response.answer_text: It depends on what I want to know. I shared a second draft of a short story once to a few people because I had not written fiction for 15 years and I wanted to know if the basic story was engaging enough for people to read the whole thing. In general, I do not share initial drafts. I might share a few paragraphs if I’m having difficulty resolving a scene and need input.

response.answer_text: Oh Gawd! I’d never subject my most trusted readers to a first or second draft. Their eyes would bleed. By the time anyone reads my work, I maintain two essential points: I provide an exciting story void of common grammatical errors and worthy of their time.I’m always open to their input, no matter their critiques.I believe that the reader is to whom I write. So I must write well.

response.answer_text: I don’t believe in it. I don’t believe in beta readers either. I only share with professionals I respect. That said, there could be exceptions. My new book is set in Morocco. I had to cancel my trip, so I could not go (why is a long story). But I am finishing it anyway and will probably have to find a Moroccan teenager to read it to save me from big faux pas.

response.answer_text: The first person with whom I share any manuscript is an editor. When I feel the book is ready for professional editing, and possibly publication, I let the editor read the “mumbltith” draft, but until that, no one gets to see it.

response.answer_text: Depends on the manuscript. Some, I’ve shared even the first draft publicly, which can still be found on Wattpad. Some writers are encouraged by sharing in-progress work. Some writers are discouraged by it. Do what works for you.

The last four books I wrote for Amazon, I did not reveal anything until I had it proofread by an expert. Simple grammar or spelling errors signal ‘amateur’ . . . even to a family member. Best to get a proof-reader to spot them so you can eradicate them before your audience spots them and judges you incompetent.

response.answer_text: I make it a habit of not talking about what I am writing until it is done. If you tell someone that you are writing a book, most will not believe you because they can't write a book and you can't be better than they are.

response.answer_text: I have two very close friends who I share bits with as I write, and I talk to them about potential plots because they sometimes see problems that I don’t. But they are not writers and I trust them implicitly.

response.answer_text: I wait and wait and wait and wait and even after Word Perfect and Perfect It! and my professional edit I still wait and wait until the publisher practically has to come over and tear it out of my hands.

response.answer_text: Depends. I no longer am writing novel length. When I has a writing buddy I'd share early but not sloppy drafts. No typos etc. I'd also share as soon as I felt stuck! Needing input.

response.answer_text: I only share my manuscript when I have polished it until it sparkles and I literally cannot think of anything else I would do to it. Then and only then is input valuable.

response.answer_text: That depends on trust, most of all. I told my closest friends about my idea. Then I asked one or two ofthem for help with things they knew more sbout than I did.
